h3. Problem Definition
It is possible to crash Confluence using external scripts with an unauthenticated user. For example, if you run the following on Confluence overnight (the scripts take some time to run), you can cause an OutOfMemoryError and database connection pool exhaustion:
{code}
sudo nmap -v -A -p8090 --script "default or safe or intrusive" -oA wikitest -T3 localhost
{code}

After some time, Confluence throws the following in the logs:
{noformat}
2017-07-12 17:39:22,666 WARN [C3P0PooledConnectionPoolManager[identityToken->1bqujhv9pfri7zh1jgbfti|3ac74bf5]-HelperThread-#2] [mchange.v2.async.ThreadPoolAsynchronousRunner] log An Error forced the closing of Thread[C3P0PooledConnectionPoolManager[identityToken->1bqujhv9pfri7zh1jgbfti|3ac74bf5]-HelperThread-#2,5,main]. Will attempt to reconstruct, but this might mean that something bad is happening.
java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: Java heap space
{noformat}

h3. Suggested Solution
If there is an unauthenticated request to Confluence, and anonymous access is disabled, Confluence can return a smaller response to avoid exhausting resources. 
 
h3. Workaround 
The script was run on a standalone server without any sort of proxy or load balancer. 
 You can make your network configuration more robust to harden the setup, for example by setting up a load balancer or proxy in front of Confluence.
fields.summary: Prevent unauthenticated users from affecting Confluence performance

fields.description:
We use a <composite-id> type in hibernate for the EVENTS table (because synchrony has two columns as a composite id). However, hibernate treats entities with composite ids differently to entities with an id field. Specifically, hibernate when being asked what the id of an entity is (which is what we do to get a handle during export), it returns the entire entity object as the id.

We keep around these "transient" ids in our xml export to make sure we don't duplicate etc. The code that uses these ids assume that they are small.

We will have to re-implement it with a composite id class, and hopefully, that will fix the issue.
fields.summary: Large synchrony EVENTS table leads to OOM during XML Site Backup

Confluence starts up correctly connected to MySQL 5.7

2017-07-07 14:03:18,634 WARN [C3P0PooledConnectionPoolManager[identityToken->z8kfsx9p8k5ul21q6rg1z|5ca418bc]-HelperThread-#1] [mchange.v2.resourcepool.BasicResourcePool] log Having failed to acquire a resource, com.mchange.v2.resourcepool.BasicResourcePool@45c5dcf5 is interrupting all Threads waiting on a resource to check out. Often, on startup, especially on an upgrade, the plugin cache can become corrupted with invalid Add-Ons. This often causes issues for customers and support tickets.

Please note the similar bug
* [CONFSERVER\-54123: Confluence plugins have version errors on start up causing incompatability|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-54123]

In {{atlassian-confluence.log}} we can see errors like

2017-08-24 22:38:17,847 ERROR [FelixDispatchQueue] [osgi.container.felix.FelixOsgiContainerManager] frameworkEvent Framework error in bundle org.randombits.support.core

2017-07-30 09:45:48,035 ERROR [localhost-startStop-1] [plugin.osgi.factory.OsgiPluginInstalledHelper] availableForTraversal Cannot determine required plugins, cannot resolve bundle 'com.atlassian.confluence.extra.bobswift-graphviz'

h2. Suggested Solution
The directories
* <confluence.home>/bundled-plugins/
* <confluence.home>/plugins-cache/
* <confluence.home>/plugins-osgi-cache/
* <confluence.home>/plugins-temp/
* <confluence.home>/bundled-plugins_language/

For support we often have to ask customers to do this when we see OSGI version errors, or other side effects after start up causing instability.

* there may be a left over jar file from a removed Add-On still in the plugin directory that Confluence tries to load
* On upgrade from Java 7 to Java 8 the jar files need to be completely rebuilt

Support will usually point customers to one of these documents
* https://confluence.atlassian.com/confkb/how-to-manually-remove-malfunctioning-add-ons-113705118.html
* https://confluence.atlassian.com/confkb/how-to-clear-confluence-plugins-cache-297664846.html

This is a related bug, where an Add-On is invalid on upgrade and needs to be removed from the database and disk
* https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-51958

# Shut down Confluence
# Delete the all the files and folders in (may need adjusting for your environment)
#* <confluence.home>/bundled-plugins
#* <confluence.home>/plugins-cache
#* <confluence.home>/plugins-osgi-cache
#* <confluence.home>/plugins-temp
#* <confluence.home>/bundled-plugins_language (might not exist)
# Restart Confluence

h3. Problem Definition
When viewing {{application.xml}} memory statistics from a Linux machine we see
{code}
<committed-virtual-memory>7,351,541,760</committed-virtual-memory>
<total-swap-space>17,024,675,840</total-swap-space>
<free-swap-space>17,024,671,744</free-swap-space>
<total-physical-memory>16,669,208,576</total-physical-memory>
<free-physical-memory>892,989,440</free-physical-memory>  
{code}
But the value for {{free-physical-memory}} isn't correct. Linux will use all non-allocated memory for a file/buffer cache that is freed up. You can see this when you run {{free}}
{code}
              total        used        free      shared  buff/cache   available
Mem:       16278524     5107416     1211784      786512     9959324    10042352
Swap:      16625660           4    16625656
{code}
The value for {{available}} is the true number of free RAM, where as STP reports the completely unused RAM value.

See
* http://www.linuxatemyram.com/

for more info.

h3. Suggested Solution
Output the available memory

h3. Why this is important
The information on memory is used by Support to determine if Linux is likely to run out of memory an OOM kill the process. Reporting on actual available memory will allow engineers to have a better idea of the stability of the machine.

h3. Workaround 
Use {{free}} or {{top}} to see actual available memory.

div[id^="jira-issues-"] { display: none; }
div[class^="refresh-issues-bottom"] { display: none; }
{code}
 # We can remove all icons (issue types and priority) in order to avoid these calls to JIRA:
 ## Go to Confluence Administration > PDF Stylesheet
 ## Add it there:
{code:java}
img.icon {  display: none !important; }
{code}
 # If you still need to have the JIRA Issues Macro results in the PDF exports, we can only improve the performance a little bit:
 ## It helps a bit if we remove the _Issue Type_ column from the JIRA Issues Macros.
 ## It also helps a bit if we set the class *com.atlassian.confluence.extra.flyingpdf.ConfluenceExportUserAgent* to ERROR level instead the default. [See this|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/configuring-logging-181535215.html] to understand how to set it.
 ## To completely avoid the performance issues that the PDF exports may cause, we can disable the plugin *Confluence PDF Export* which handles the task
 # Export to Word instead
 # Disable the *excerpt* and *excerpt-include* modules of the *Advanced Macros* plugin (Manage Add-ons > Select _All add-ons_ on the dropdown menu > search for Advanced Macros > Expand its modules > disabled the ones mentioned above).
